questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of swelling in the lower limb, non-pitting edema and lymphadenopathy. The doctor wants to perform lymphangiography; how is it performed?

options.label: A
options.text: An injection of sodium diatrizoate (Hypaque) subcutaneously between the toes

options.label: B
options.text: Injection of sodium diatrizoate retrogradely under pressure into a small vein on the dorsum of the foot

options.label: C
options.text: Dissecting lymphatics through an incision on the dorsum of the foot

options.label: D
options.text: The use of an infusion pump

questions.correct_answer: C. Dissecting lymphatics through an incision on the dorsum of the foot
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dissecting lymphatics through an incision on the dorsum of the foot Lymphangiography is performed by injecting coloured dye into the hand or foot.

Highyeild:

Lymphangiography Radiologic lymphangiography is performed by first visualising the lymphatics by injecting coloured dye into the hand or foot. The visualized lymphatic segment is exposed through a small incision and cannulated with a 27- to 30-gauge needle. An oil-based dye is then injected slowly into the lymphatics over several hours. The lymphatic channels and nodes are then visualised with traditional radiographs. Lymphangiography is reserved for patients with lymphangiectasia or lymphatic fistulas and patients being considered for mic rovascular reconstruction. Lymphoscintigraphy and Duplex ultrasound are other diagnostic techniques commonly used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B & D - Other methods like infusion pump, injection between toes or injection into a small vein on the dorsum of the foot are not preferred because that may not show an exact picture of the whole lymphatic system.

questions.text: A mother complains of swelling of the right lower limb of the male baby after birth; Edema is present, which is not pitting. Family history is significant, and lymphangiography is done (image). Which among the following is a pattern according to lymphangiographic classification?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital hyperplasia Congenital hyperplasia (10%) of lymphatics is seen in males> females , involves the whole leg, u/l=b/l, and family history is significant and progressive. Response to compression therapy is variable. Lymphatics are increased in number; although functionally defective, there is usually an increased number of lymph nodes. May have chylous ascites, chylothorax and protein-losing enteropathy.

Highyeild:

The visualized lymphatic segment is exposed through a small incision and cannulated with a 27- to 30-gauge needle. An oil-based dye is then injected slowly into the lymphatics over several hours. The lymphatic channels and nodes are then visualised with traditional radiographs. Lymphangiography is reserved for patients with lymphangiectasia or lymphatic fistulas and patients being considered for mic rovascular reconstruction. Lymphoscintigraphy and Duplex ultrasound are other diagnostic techniques commonly used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B - Proximal obliteration (10%)-Any age, Male=female, Whole leg, thigh only, usually unilateral. No family history, Rapid in progression. Response compression therapy is poor. There is obstruction at the level of the aortoiliac or inguinal nodes. The patient may benefit from a lymphatic bypass operation if associated with distal dilatation. Other patients have distal obliteration as well. Option C - Distal obliteration (80%)- Puberty (praecox), Female > male, Ankle, calf, often bilateral, family history is often positive, Slow in progression. Response to compression therapy is good. Absent or reduced distal superficial lymphatics. Also termed aplasia or hypoplasia.

questions.text: An elderly lady visits surgical OPD with complaints of long-standing symptoms of lower limb swelling, Edema, dermal thickening and squaring of toes. What would be the best investigation for this patient to proceed further?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphoscintigraphy Lymphoscintigraphy is the investigation of choice for lymphatic disorders from the given options.

Highyeild:

Lymphoscintigraphy has become the most common, but still overall uncommonly, used diagnostic test to identify lymphatic abnormalities. It has primarily replaced lymphangiography . A radiolabeled sulfur colloid (technetium 99 m sulfur colloid) is injected into the subdermal, interdigital region of the affected limb. The lymphatic transport is monitored with a whole-body gamma camera, and primary lymphatics and nodes can be visualized. Tracer activity may be detected in the inguinal region within 15 to 60 minutes in normal individuals. Within 3 hours, uptake should be present in the pelvic and abdominal lymph nodes. In patients with lymphedema, various patterns may be seen on lymphoscintigraphy. There may be delayed or absent transport to the inguinal nodes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A -It provides useful information about the venous function, including DVT and other venous abnormalities. Option C - A single, axial computed tomography (CT) slice through the mid-calf has been proposed as a useful diagnostic test for lymphoedema (coarse, non-enhancing, reticular 'honeycomb pattern in an enlarged subcutaneous compartment), venous oedema (increased volume of the muscular compartment) and lipoedema (increased subcutaneous fat). CT can also be used to exclude pelvic or abdominal mass lesions. It can also be used to monitor response to treatment through serial measurements of cross-sectional area and tissue density. Option D - More recently, fluorescent molecules, such as indocyanine green (ICG), are being used to image the superficial lymphatic system. When excited using appropriate light energy, these molecules emit photons with a different wavelength that can be detected using dedicated near-infrared imaging devices, providing excellent anatomic and functional details of the lymphatic system. This imaging is increasingly being used to study the lymphatic system and the effects of some therapies.

Extraedge:

Lymphedema is not curable, but the symptoms and long-term effects can be controlled with a combination of elastic compression stockings, limb elevation, pneumatic compression, and massage. Controlling the edema protects the skin and potentially prevents cellulitis

questions.text: Which of the following operation is not done for congenital lymphedema?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

De Quervain’s operation De Quervain’s operation involves surgical release of the first dorsal compartment with care to fully release the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) from their respective sheaths while protecting the radial sensory nerve to decompress the extensor tendons. This operation is used for De Quervians disease or Extensor tenosynovitis.

Highyeild:

Lymphedema - Treatment : General Therapeutic Measures : Appropriate Antibiotics Maintenance of ideal body weight Elevation and Compression Garments : The ideal compression garment is custom-fitted and delivers 30 to 60 mm Hg pressures. Limb Elevation at night Avoid standing for prolonged periods Complex Decongestive Physical Therapy Compression Pump Therapy (Pneumatic Compression therapy) Drug Therapy - Benzopyrones Molecular Lymphangiogenesis Operative Treatment : Reconstructive - should be considered for those patients with proximal (either primary or secondary) obstruction of the extremity lymphatic circulation with preserved, dilated lymphatics peripheral to the obstruction. Excisional - only viable option for patients without residual lymphatics of adequate size for reconstructive procedures. For patients with recalcitrant stage II and early stage III lymphedema in whom the edema is moderate and the skin is relatively healthy, an excisional procedure that removes a large segment of the lymphedematous subcutaneous tissues and the overlying skin is the procedure of choice. Surgical options for lymphoedema Bypass procedures- Lymphatic bypass, e.g., omental pedicle, the skin bridge (Gillies) and the ilal mucosal patch (Kinmonth) Lymphaticovenular anastomosis (LVA) Lymph nodes to vein anastomosis Liposuction Limb reduction procedures include the following- Sistrunk Homans Thompson Charles

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with swollen limb and edema which impaired his mobility and livelihood, not controlled by conservative management for this surgeon performed this procedure(image). What is that procedure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homans The picture shows the Homans Operation as the skin flaps are elevated, and subcutaneous tissue is excised, trimmed and accommodated. HOMANS - First, skin flaps are elevated, and then subcutaneous tissue is excised from beneath the flaps, trimming to size to accommodate the reduced girth of the limb and closed primarily. This is the most satisfactory operation for the calf. The main complication is skin flap necrosis. There must be at least 6 months between operations on the medial and lateral sides of the limb, and the flaps must not pass the midline.

questions.text: The drug of choice in cellulitis associated with lymphedema is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Penicillin Staphylococcus and β-hemolytic Streptococcus are the most common organisms causing soft tissue infection. The drug of choice is penicillin or a cephalosporin active against Streptococcus for 5 day.

Highyeild:

Antibiotic Therapy in the management of Lymphedema : Patients with lymphedema are at increased risk of developing cellulitis in the affected extremity due to microscopic breakdown in the skin barrier either secondary to swelling or unrecognized and untreated tinea pedis. Recurrent infection can damage the lymphatics, aggravating the edema and increasing the risk for subsequent infection. Staphylococcus and β-hemolytic Streptococcus are the most common organisms causing soft tissue infection. Aggressive antibiotic therapy and elevation with compression are recommended at the earliest signs or symptoms of cellulitis. The drug of choice is penicillin or a cephalosporin active against Streptococcus for 5 days. In patients with recurrent cellulitis, despite methods to reduce oedema, treatment with monthly intramuscular injections of benzathine penicillin 1.2 MU, twice-daily erythromycin 250 mg, or penicillin V 1 g daily has proven effective at suppression

questions.text: Choose the correct answer for Compression Garments in the management of Lymphedema The amount of compression required for controlling lymphedema ranges from 10 to 20 mmHg The stockings should be worn during waking hours Graded compression stockings are often the first recommended intervention Select the correct the answer from the given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

F, T, F The amount of compression required for controlling lymphedema ranges from 30 to 60 mmHg The stockings should be worn during waking hours Leg Elevation is often the first recommended intervention

Highyeild:

Graded compression stockings are widely used in the treatment of lymphedema. The stockings reduce the amount of swelling in the involved extremity by decreasing edema accumulation while the extremity is dependent. Compression stockings have been associated with long-term maintenance of reduced limb circumference when worn daily. They may also protect the tissues against chronically elevated intrinsic pressures, which lead to skin and subcutaneous tissue thickening. Compression stockings also offer protection against external trauma that may lead to cellulitis. The compression required for controlling lymphedema ranges from 20 to 60 mmHg and varies among patients. The stockings can be custom-made or prefabricated and are available in above- and below-knee lengths. The stockings should be worn during waking hours. The garments should be replaced approximately every 6 months when they lose elasticity.

questions.text: What is the pressure range for the most effective demonstration of IPC in lymphedema patients?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30 -60 mm Hg IPC pressure ranges between 30 and 60 mmHg demonstrated to be most effective

Highyeild:

Intermittent Pneumatic Compression Therapy. The use of IPC with a single-chamber or multi-chamber pump temporarily reduces edema and provides another adjunct to the use of compression stockings . These devices effectively reduce limb volume; however, compression stockings are necessary to maintain the volume reduction when the patient is no longer supine because fluid transport is not associated with the transport of macromolecules (proteins) from the tissue. Typically, IPC is used for 4 to 6 hours per day at home when the patient is supine, with pressure ranges between 30 and 60 mmHg demonstrated to be most effective.
